messages: df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:24): wyrd33: That very much depends on what it is. If it's an application, longer waits are more acceptable on initial load
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:27): wyrd33: If size becomes an issue, pack the code
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:27): wyrd33: Often you can get it down to one third the size
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:35): I am working on an application where I so far have about 400kb of uncompressed js
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:35): When removing comments and unneeded whitespace I get to about 200kb
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:36): if I pack that I get about 150kb
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:36): if I gzip that it gets down to a lot less
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:36): definately under the pain limit
62fba5811243f518935848d952809f8c (12:37): Now, what's the size difference between gz and (-comments)+pack+gz?
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:38): I havent measured it yet since we arent anywhere close to releasing it yet
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:39): It cant be much
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:39): but the comments removal and packing is mainly because the boss is paranoid and hasnt understood that basicly you cant hide javascript
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:40): I dont care as long as I can just make those things part of my normal buildscript
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:41): What about using Dean Edwards's packer?
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:41): Ah.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:41): The perl version
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:41): Kewl.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:42): For size yes. Other than that I dont see the point
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:42): People who can understand the code are good enough to be able to come up with it themselves
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:42): Especially for large applications where everything is bound together in wierd ways
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:42): Are you talking about obfuscation?
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:43): I brought it up in relation to compression.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:43): yes. The boss wants the packer because of the obfuscating ability
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:43): Oh.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:43): Not that anyone cant just unpack it
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:43): No, of course not.  That would be unthinkable... 8-)
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:43): And I really dont care to make a real obfuscator
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:44): You'd be wasting your time anyway.
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:44): It's like the encryption on DVDs... you have to hand the end-user the key, the lock and what you've locked.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:45): But the ood thing about JS is that the people who are able to break the encryption, dont need to
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:45): Locked away, perhaps.
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:45): True.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:45): They can much more easily reverse engineer it
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:45): And in the process adapt it to their needs
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:45): munter: the reason i was asking is that the prototype and scriptaculous libs seem fairly large
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:46): wyrd33: They are. Cut down on the parts you don tuse
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:46): Or use jQuery.
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:46): http://jquery.com/
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:46): Its just yet another abstraction layer
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:46): It's a different library altogether with the primary goal being able to pack as much as they can in as little space (around 10K) as possible.
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:47): I prefer do code in javascript, not in jQuery, scripaculous or whatever they are all called

a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:47): I'm not getting into which one is "better", since that's a stupid argument anyway, but jQuery is certainly smaller (and probably has proportionately fewer features).
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:47): ah.. im more or less looking for effects though
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:47): in 10k i can do a LOT of stuff
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:47): moo.fx looks pretty good for only 3k, and they have "prototype.lite" which is also 4k
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:48): Munter: Go ahead, no one's stopping you. :-)
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:49): How about a tree menu in ~20 lines? How much space would that take with any of thos libs?
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:49): *shrugs* im just starting to familiarize myself with them, but creating drag and drop between two menus (lists) is two lines of code with scriptaculous
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:50): correct, that takes a bit more if you do it yourself
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:51): However i did it anyway, because I had to do drag/drop across frames
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:51): browsers do cache the javascript files though, right?
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:51): As long as they're regular .js files, yes.
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:52): so if you have gzip enabled with your CMS or your own homebrew php framework (or lang of choice), it should decrease the size even further, right?
a06799ba5c7fbc1cd9f0fe0c683c6ee2 (12:53): Yuh.
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:54): so 150kish is acceptable then? im still trying to get a feel of what the standard is
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:56): That depends on your audience and their expectations
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:56): 150kb is not acceptable for a website imo
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:57): all the frameworks i've looked at with capabilities such as drag and drop are fairly large
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:57): However, for some type of application, where the user possible gets a loading screen or something like it, it might look different
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:57): Thats because those frmeworks tend to come with the kitchen sink
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:57): Just cut them
df52db578d711579b9cc26c94d8b3d41 (12:57): unless some license prevents you from it
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:58): well, for the drag and drop stuff it'd be more or less for an admin menu
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:58): looking at scriptaculous drag and drop .. it depends on their effects.js, which is another 30k. so splitting those scripts obviously wont happen
5ca5a0a9116c74005c4a7781670de639 (12:58): i'll take another look at dojo
